sen.j: 南禅寺 （なんぜんじ）は、京都市左京区南禅寺福地町にある、臨済宗南禅寺派大本山の寺院である。
sen.e: Nanzen-ji Temple, located in Nanzenji-fukuchi-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City is the headquarters of the Nanzenji branch of the Rinzai Sect of Zen Buddhism
Nanzen-ji Temple, located in Nanzen-ji-fukuchi-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City is the headquarters of the Nanzen-ji branch of the Rinzai Sect of Zen Buddhism.
Nanzen-ji Temple, located in Nanzen-ji-fukuchi-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the headquarters of the Nanzen-ji branch of the Rinzai Sect of Zen Buddhism.

sen.j: 山号は瑞龍山、寺号は詳しくは太平興国南禅禅寺（たいへいこうこくなんぜんぜんじ）と称する。
sen.e: The honorific mountain prefix is 'Zuiryusan' and it goes under the formal title of Taiheikokoku-Nanzen-Zenji.
The honorific mountain prefix is 'Zuiryusan' and it goes under the formal title of Taiheikokoku-Nanzen-Zenji.
The honorific mountain prefix is Zuiryusan and it goes under the formal title of Taiheikokoku-Nanzen-Zenji.

sen.j: 本尊は釈迦如来、開基（創立者）は亀山天皇、開山（初代住職）は無関普門（大明国師）。
sen.e: The temple was founded by kaiki (founding patron) Emperor Kameyama and kaizan (first chief priest) Mukan Fumon (Daimyo-kokushi).
sen.cmt: ・Emperor Kameyama: http://kotobank.jp/word/亀山天皇・Daimyo-kokushi: http://kotobank.jp/word/大明国師
sen.e: The temple was founded by kaiki (founding patron) Emperor Kameyama and kaisan (first chief priest) Mukan Fumon (Daimyo-kokushi), and its principal image is Shakyamuni (Buddha).
sen.cmt: 「本尊は釈迦如来」の訳を補足kaizan→kaisan
sen.e: The temple was founded by kaiki (founding patron) Emperor Kameyama and kaisan (first chief priest) Mukan Fumon (Daimyo-kokushi), and its principal image is Shakyamuni (Buddha).

sen.j: 京都五山の上におかれる別格扱いの寺院で、日本の禅寺のなかで最も高い格式を誇る。
sen.e: It is not itself one of the Kyoto Gozan (Five Great Zen Temples of Kyoto) but presides over them all and holds the highest rank of all Japan's Zen temples.
It is not itself one of the Kyoto Gozan (Five Great Zen Temples of Kyoto) but presides over them all and holds the highest rank of all Japan's Zen temples.
It is not itself one of the Kyoto Gozan (Five Great Zen Temples of Kyoto) but presides over them all and holds the highest rank of all Japan's Zen temples.

sen.j: また皇室の発願になる禅寺としては日本で最初のものである。
sen.e: It was also the first temple in Japan to be founded by the Emperor.
It was also the first temple in Japan to be founded by the Emperor.
It was also the first temple in Japan to be founded by the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Emperor→Imperial family 原文に合わせる

sen.j: 南禅寺の建立以前、この地には、後嵯峨天皇が文永元年（1264年）に造営した離宮の禅林寺殿（ぜんりんじどの）があった。
sen.e: Before Nanzen-ji Temple was founded, the site was the location of Emperor Gosaga's detached palace Zenrinji-dono Palace.
Before Nanzen-ji Temple was founded, the site was the location of Emperor Gosaga's detached palace Zenrin-ji-dono Palace, which was built in 1264.
sen.cmt: Zenrin-jiに訂正。which was built in 1264を補足。
sen.e: Before Nanzen-ji Temple was founded, the site was the location of Emperor Gosaga's detached palace Zenrin-ji-dono Palace, which was built in 1264.

sen.j: 「禅林寺殿」の名は、南禅寺の北に現存する浄土宗西山禅林寺派総本山の禅林寺 (京都市)（永観堂）に由来する。
sen.e: The palace was named 'Zenrinji-dono' after Eikan-do, the headquarters of the Seizan-Zenrinji branch of the Pure Land Sect that still stands to the north of Nanzen-ji Temple.
The palace was named 'Zenrin-ji-dono' after Eikan-do, the headquarters of the Seizan-Zenrin-ji branch of the Pure Land Sect that still stands to the north of Nanzen-ji Temple.

The palace was named 'Zenrin-ji-dono' after Zenrin-ji Temple (Kyoto City) (Eikan-do), the headquarters of the Seizan-Zenrin-ji branch of the Pure Land Sect that still stands to the north of Nanzen-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Zenrin-ji Temple (Kyoto City)補足Eikan-doを()に入れる

sen.j: この離宮は「上の御所」と「下の御所」に分かれ、うち「上の御所」に建設された持仏堂を「南禅院」と称した。
sen.e: This detached palace was divided into an upper palace and lower palace and the Jibutsu-do private Buddhist worship area) of the lower palace was named 'Nanzen-in'.
This detached palace was divided into an upper palace and lower palace and the Jibutsu-do (private Buddhist worship area) of the upper palace was named 'Nanzen-in'.
sen.cmt: private→(private of the lower→of the upper
sen.e: This detached palace was divided into an upper palace and lower palace and the Jibutsu-do (private Buddhist worship area) of the upper palace was named 'Nanzen-in.'

sen.j: 現存する南禅寺の塔頭（たっちゅう）・南禅院はその後身である。
sen.e: The surviving Nanzen-ji Temple sub-temples were constructed later.
The surviving sub-temple of Nanzen-ji Temple, 'Nanzen-in,' was constructed later.
sen.cmt: 塔頭(たっちゅう)=南禅院
sen.e: The surviving sub-temple of Nanzen-ji Temple, Nanzen-in, was constructed later.

sen.j: 亀山上皇は正応2年（1289年）、40歳の時に落飾（剃髪して仏門に入る）して法皇となった。
sen.e: In 1289 at age 40, Emperor Kameyama abdicated, shaved his head and became a monk.
In 1289 at age 40, Emperor Kameyama abdicated, shaved his head and became a monk.
In 1289 at age 40, Emperor Kameyama abdicated, shaved his head and became a monk.

sen.j: 2年後の正応4年（1291年）、法皇は禅林寺殿を寺にあらため、当時80歳の無関普門を開山として、これを龍安山禅林禅寺と名づけた。
sen.e: Two years later in 1291, he converted Zenrinji-dono Palace into a temple and invited the 80 year old Mukan Fumon to serve as chief priest of the temple which was named 'Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zenji'.

Two years later in 1291, he converted Zenrin-ji-dono Palace into a temple and invited the 80 year old Mukan Fumon to serve as chief priest of the temple which was named 'Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zen-ji Temple'.
sen.cmt: Zenrin-ji, Zen-jiに訂正。Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zen-ji Templeに訂正。
sen.e: Two years later in 1291, he converted Zenrin-ji-dono Palace into a temple and invited the 80 year old Mukan Fumon to serve as chief priest of the temple which was named 'Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zen-ji Temple.'

sen.j: 伝承によれば、この頃禅林寺殿に夜な夜な妖怪変化が出没して亀山法皇やお付きの官人たちを悩ませたが、無関普門が弟子を引き連れて禅林寺殿に入り、静かに座禅をしただけで妖怪変化は退散したので、亀山法皇は無関を開山に請じたという。
sen.e: According to legend, ghosts would appear at Zenrinji-dono night after night and trouble the ex-emperor Kameyama and his staff, but Mukan Fumon brought his disciples and simply sat and meditated (zazen) until the ghosts left, which so impressed the ex-emperor that he invited Mukan to serve as chief priest.

According to legend, ghosts would appear at Zenrin-ji-dono night after night and trouble the ex-emperor Kameyama and his staff, but Mukan Fumon brought his disciples and simply sat and meditated (zazen) until the ghosts left, which so impressed the ex-emperor that he invited Mukan to serve as chief priest.

According to legend, ghosts would appear at Zenrin-ji-dono night after night and trouble the Cloistered Emperor Kameyama and his staff, but Mukan Fumon brought his disciples and simply sat and meditated (zazen) until the ghosts left, which so impressed the Cloistered Emperor that he invited Mukan to serve as chief priest.

sen.j: 無関普門は、信濃国の出身。
sen.e: Mukan Fumon was born in Shinano Province.
Mukan Fumon was born in Shinano Province.
Mukan Fumon was born in Shinano Province.

sen.j: 東福寺開山の円爾（えんに）に師事した後、40歳で北宋に留学、10年以上も修行した後、弘長2年（1262年）帰国。
sen.e: After studying under Enni, first chief priest of Tofuku-ji Temple, he left to study in Northern Song period China and returned to Japan over 10 years later in 1262.
After studying under Enni, first chief priest of Tofuku-ji Temple, he left to study in Northern Song period China and returned to Japan over 10 years later in 1262.
After studying under Enni, first chief priest of Tofuku-ji Temple, he left to study in Northern Song period China at the age of 40 and returned to Japan over 10 years later in 1262.

sen.j: 70歳になるまで自分の寺を持たず修行に専念していたが、師の円爾の死にをうけて弘安4年（1281年）に東福寺の住持となった。
sen.e: Until the age of 70, he never had his own temple and remained devoted to asceticism but assumed the post of chief priest at Tofuku-ji Temple in 1291 after the death of his teacher Enni.
Until the age of 70, he never had his own temple and remained devoted to asceticism but assumed the post of chief priest at Tofuku-ji Temple in 1281 after the death of his teacher Enni.
Until the age of 70, he never had his own temple and remained devoted to asceticism but assumed the post of chief priest at Tofuku-ji Temple in 1281 after the death of his teacher Enni.

sen.j: その10年後の正応4年（1291年）に南禅寺の開山として招かれるが、間もなく死去する。
sen.e: He was invited to serve as head priest at Nanzen-ji Temple ten years later in 1291 but passed away soon after.
He was invited to serve as head priest at Nanzen-ji Temple ten years later in 1291 but passed away soon after.
He was invited to serve as head priest at Nanzen-ji Temple ten years later in 1291 but passed away soon after.

sen.j: 開山の無関の死去に伴い、南禅寺伽藍の建設は実質的には二世住職の規庵祖円（南院国師、1261 - 1313）が指揮し、永仁7年（1299年）頃に寺観が整った。
sen.e: After the death of the founding priest, the majority of the temple's construction was conducted under 2nd chief priest Kian Soen (Daimyo Kokushi, 1261-1313) and completed around 1299.
After the death of the founding priest, the majority of the temple's construction was conducted under the 2nd chief priest Kian Soen (Nanin Kokushi, 1261-1313) and completed around 1299.
After the death of the founding priest Mukan, the majority of the temple's construction was conducted under the second chief priest Kian Soen (Nanin Kokushi, 1261 - 1313) and completed around 1299.
sen.cmt: Mukan補足2nd→secondハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 当初の「龍安山禅林禅寺」を「太平興国南禅禅寺」という寺号に改めたのは正安年間（1299 - 1302年）のことという。
sen.e: It is said that the original name 'Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zenji' was changed to 'Taiheikokoku-Nanzen-Zenji' during the Shoan era (1299-1302).
It is said that the original name 'Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zen-ji' was changed to 'Taiheikokoku-Nanzen-Zen-ji' during the Shoan era (1299-1302).
It is said that the original name 'Ryoansan-Zenrin-Zen-ji' was changed to 'Taiheikokoku-Nanzen-Zen-ji' during the Shoan era (1299 - 1302).
sen.cmt: ハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 正中 (元号)2年（1325年）には夢窓疎石が当寺に住している。
sen.e: In 1325, Muso Soseki resided at the temple.
In 1325, Muso Soseki resided at the temple.
In 1325, Muso Soseki resided at the temple.

sen.j: 建武 (日本)元年（1334年）、後醍醐天皇は南禅寺を京都五山の第一としたが、至徳 (日本)3年（1385年）に足利義満は自らの建立した相国寺を五山の第一とするために南禅寺を「別格」として五山のさらに上に位置づけた。
sen.e: In 1334, Emperor Godaigo placed Nanzen-ji Temple as number 1 of the Kyoto Gozan but in 1385 Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA placed his own Shokoku-ji Temple at number 1 so Nanzen-ji Temple was treated as a special case and ranked higher than all the Gozan temples.
sen.cmt: ・Emperor Godaigo: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=後醍醐天皇&stype=0&dtype=0・Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=足利義満&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=00354900258000・Shokoku-ji Temple: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=相国寺&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=10336009026800
sen.e: In 1334, Emperor Godaigo placed Nanzen-ji Temple as number 1 of the Kyoto Gozan but in 1385 Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA placed his own Shokoku-ji Temple at number 1 so Nanzen-ji Temple was treated as a special case and ranked higher than all the Gozan temples.

In 1334, Emperor Godaigo placed Nanzen-ji Temple as number one of the Kyoto Gozan but in 1385 Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA placed his own Shokoku-ji Temple at number one so Nanzen-ji Temple was treated as a special case and ranked higher than all the Gozan temples.

sen.j: 室町時代には旧仏教勢力の延暦寺や園城寺と対立して政治問題に発展、管領の細川頼之が調停に乗り出している。
sen.e: During the Muromachi period the temple became embroiled in political problems with the traditional temples Enryaku-ji and Onjo-ji and the Shogun's Deputy Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA stepped in to mediate.

During the Muromachi period the temple became embroiled in political problems with the traditional temples Enryaku-ji Temple and Onjo-ji Temple and the Shogun's Deputy Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA stepped in to mediate.
During the Muromachi period the temple became embroiled in political problems with the traditional temples Enryaku-ji Temple and Onjo-ji Temple and the Kanre Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA stepped in to mediate.

sen.j: 明徳4年（1393年）と文安4年（1447年）に火災に見舞われ、主要伽藍を焼失してたがほどなく再建。
sen.e: The monastery was devastated by fire in 1393 and again in 1447 but was soon rebuilt on both occasions.
The monastery was devastated by fire in 1393 and again in 1447 but was soon rebuilt on both occasions.
The monastery was devastated by fire in 1393 and again in 1447 but was soon rebuilt on both occasions.

sen.j: しかし応仁元年（1467年）、応仁の乱の市街戦で伽藍をことごとく焼失してからは再建も思うにまかせなかった。
sen.e: However, the temple was completely destroyed by fire in the street fighting during the first year of the Onin War (1467) but was once again revived.
However, the temple was completely destroyed by fire in the street fighting during the first year of the Onin War (1467), and the reconstruction did not go well.
sen.cmt: 「再建も思うにまかせなかった」を訳出。
sen.e: However, the temple was completely destroyed by fire in the street fighting during the first year of the Onin War (1467), and the reconstruction did not go well.

sen.j: 南禅寺の復興が進んだのは、江戸時代になって慶長10年（1605年）以心崇伝が入寺してからである。
sen.e: The revival of Nanzen-ji Temple was continued during the Edo period by Ishin Suden who entered the temple in 1605.
The revival of Nanzen-ji Temple was continued during the Edo period by Ishin Suden who entered the temple in 1605.
The revival of Nanzen-ji Temple was continued during the Edo period by Ishin Suden who entered the temple in 1605.

sen.j: 崇伝は徳川家康の側近として外交や寺社政策に携わり、「黒衣の宰相」と呼ばれた政治家でもあった。
sen.e: As a close associate of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, Suden was also a politician known as 'Kokui-no-Saisho' who was involved in diplomacy and the administration of Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples.
As a close associate of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, Suden was also a politician known as 'Kokui-no-Saisho' who was involved in diplomacy and the administration of Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples.
As a close associate of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, Suden was also a politician known as 'Kokui-no-Saisho' who was involved in diplomacy and the administration of Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples.

sen.j: また、幕府から「僧録」という地位を与えられた。
sen.e: He was also given the personnell management post of Soroku by the Shogunate.
He was also given the personnel management post of Soroku by the Shogunate.
He was also given the personnel management post of Soroku by the Shogunate.

sen.j: これは日本全国の臨済宗寺院の元締めにあたる役職である。
sen.e: This role was responsible for all of the Rinzai Sect temples in Japan.
This role was responsible for all of the Rinzai Sect temples in Japan.
This role was responsible for all of the Rinzai Sect temples in Japan.

sen.j: なお南禅寺境内は平成17年（2005年）に国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: Nanzen-ji Temple precinct was nationally designated a historic site in 2005.
Nanzen-ji Temple precinct was nationally designated a historic site in 2005.
Nanzen-ji Temple precinct was nationally designated a historic site in 2005.

sen.j: 勅使門
sen.e: Chokushimon Gate (gate for imperial envoys)
Chokushi-mon Gate (gate for imperial envoys)
Chokushi-mon Gate (gate for imperial envoys)

sen.j: 寛永18年（1641年年）、御所の日ノ御門を移築したものという。
sen.e: Said to have been relocated from the old imperial palace in 1641.
Said to have been relocated from Hinomikado, the old imperial palace in 1641.
Said to have been relocated from Hinomikado, the old imperial palace in 1641.

sen.j: 三門
sen.e: San-mon Gate
Sam-mon Gate
Sanmon Gate

sen.j: 歌舞伎の『楼門五三桐』（さんもんごさんのきり）の二幕返しで石川五右衛門が「絶景かな絶景かな」という名台詞を吐く「南禅寺山門」がこれである。
sen.e: In the second act of the kabuki drama 'Sanmon Gosan-no-Kiri', Goemon ISHIKAWA's famous words 'What an amazing view' are in reference to the san-mon gate of Nanzen-ji Temple.
In the second act of the kabuki drama 'Sam-mon Gosan-no-Kiri', Goemon ISHIKAWA's famous words 'What an amazing view' are in reference to the Sam-mon Gate of Nanzen-ji Temple.
In the second act of the kabuki drama "Sanmon Gosan-no-Kiri," Goemon ISHIKAWA's famous words 'What an amazing view' are in reference to the Sanmon Gate of Nanzen-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: カンマを'の中に移動 'Sam-mon Gosan-no-Kiri,'→ "Sanmon Gosan-no-Kiri,"に変更しました。

sen.j: ただしそれは創作上の話で、実際の三門は五右衛門の死後30年以上経った寛永5年（1628年）の建築。
sen.e: However, this only occurs in the story as the actual san-mon gate was constructed in 1628, more that 30 years after the death of Goemon ISHIKAWA.
However, this only occurs in the story as the actual Sam-mon Gate was constructed in 1628, more that 30 years after the death of Goemon ISHIKAWA.
However, this only occurs in the story as the actual Sam-mon Gate was constructed in 1628, more than 30 years after the death of Goemon ISHIKAWA.

sen.j: 五間三戸（正面柱間が5間で、うち中央3間が出入口）の二重門（2階建ての門）。
sen.e: It is two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances (of the five front bays, the middle three serve as entrances).
It is two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances (of the five front bays, the middle three serve as entrances).
It is two-storey gate with five bays and three entrances (of the five front bays, the middle three serve as entrances).

sen.j: 藤堂高虎が大坂の役で戦死した一門の武士たちの冥福を祈るため寄進したものである。
sen.e: It was dedicated by Takatora TODO as a memorial to the soldiers who died during the Siege of Osaka in 1616.
It was dedicated by Takatora TODO as a memorial to the soldiers who died during the Siege of Osaka.
It was dedicated by Takatora TODO as a memorial to the soldiers who died during the Siege of Osaka.

sen.j: 上層は「五鳳楼」といい、釈迦如来と阿羅漢のほか、寄進者の藤堂家歴代の位牌、大坂の陣の戦死者の位牌などを安置する。
sen.e: The upper level is known as 'Gohoro' and houses numerous treasures including a statue of Shaka Nyorai, statues of arhats, memorial tablets of member's of the benefactor Takatora TODO's family and memorial tablets of those who died in the Siege of Osaka.

The upper level is known as 'Gohoro' and houses a statue of Shaka Nyorai, statues of arhats, memorial tablets of member's of the benefactor TODO family and memorial tablets of those who died in the Siege of Osaka and others.
sen.cmt: numerous treasures includingを削除。TODO family に訂正。and othersを補足。
sen.e: The upper level is known as 'Gohoro' and houses a statue of Shaka Nyorai, statues of arhats, memorial tablets of member's of the benefactor TODO family and memorial tablets of those who died in the Siege of Osaka and others.

sen.j: 天井画の天人と鳳凰の図は狩野探幽筆。
sen.e: The image of celestial maidens and Chinese phoenixes on the ceiling was painted by Tanshin KANO.
The image of celestial maidens and Chinese phoenixes on the ceiling was painted by Tanshin KANO.
The image of celestial maidens and Chinese phoenixes on the ceiling was painted by Tanshin KANO.

sen.j: 知恩院三門、東本願寺御影堂門とともに、京都三大門の一つに数えられている。
sen.e: It is considered one of the three great gates of Kyoto along with the san-mon gate of Chion-in Temple and Mieido-mon gate of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple.
It is considered one of the three great gates of Kyoto along with the Sam-mon Gate of Chion-in Temple and Mieido-mon Gate of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple.
It is considered one of the three great gates of Kyoto along with the Sam-mon Gate of Chion-in Temple and Mieido-mon Gate of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 法堂（はっとう）
sen.e: Hatto (Lecture Hall)
Hatto (Lecture Hall)
Hatto (Lecture Hall)

sen.j: 明治28年（1895年）にこたつの火の不始末で焼失した後、明治42年（1909年）に再建されたもの。
sen.e: Destroyed by fire in 1895 when the charcoal brazier was not properly extinguished but rebuilt in 1909.
Destroyed by fire in 1895 when the charcoal brazier was not properly extinguished but rebuilt in 1909.
Destroyed by fire in 1895 when the charcoal brazier of kotatsu (fireplace with a coverlet) was not properly extinguished but rebuilt in 1909.
sen.cmt: of kotatsu (fireplace with a coverlet)補足

sen.j: 方丈
sen.e: Hojo (Abbots' Quarters)
Hojo (Abbots' Quarters)
Hojo (Abbots' Quarters)

sen.j: 国宝。
sen.e: National Treasure.
National Treasure.
National Treasure

sen.j: 大方丈と小方丈からなる。
sen.e: Composed of the larger Ohojo and smaller Kohojo.
Composed of the larger Ohojo and smaller Kohojo.
Composed of the larger Ohojo and smaller Kohojo.

sen.j: 大方丈は慶長度の御所建て替えに際し、天正建設の旧御所の建物を下賜されたもの。
sen.e: The Ohojo was formerly a Tensho era imperial palace building that was granted to the temple when the Keicho era imperial palace complex underwent reconstruction.
The Ohojo was formerly a Tensho era imperial palace building that was granted to the temple when the Keicho era imperial palace complex underwent reconstruction.
The Ohojo was formerly a Tensho era imperial palace building that was granted to the temple when the Keicho era imperial palace complex underwent reconstruction.

sen.j: 「旧御所清涼殿を移築した」とする資料が多いが、清涼殿ではなく女院御所の対面御殿を移築したものである。
sen.e: There many sources that claim that it was the old Seiryo-den palace building that was relocated but it was actually the building that stood opposite the Nyoin-gosho palace.
There many sources that claim that it was the old Seiryo-den palace building that was relocated but it was actually the building that stood opposite the Nyoin-gosho palace.
There are many sources that claim that it was the old Seiryo-den palace building that was relocated but it was in fact the building that stood opposite the Nyoin-gosho palace.
sen.cmt: are補足"actually"→"in fact"に変更しました。

sen.j: 接続して建つ小方丈は寛永の建築とされる。
sen.e: The attached Ohojo is believed to have been constructed during the Kan'ei era (1624-1643).
The attached Kohojo is believed to have been constructed during the Kan'ei era (1624-1643).
The attached Kohojo is believed to have been constructed during the Kanei era (1624-1643).

sen.j: 大方丈には狩野派の絵師による障壁画があり、柳の間・麝香の間・御昼の間・花鳥の間（西の間）・鶴の間・鳴滝の間の各間にある襖や壁貼付など計120面が重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: A total of 120 sliding screen and paper wall paintings, all dedicated Important Cultural Properties, done by artists of the Kano school adorn the rooms of the Ohojo which includes the willow room, musk room, lunch room, flower and bird room (west room), crane room and Narutaki room.

A total of 120 sliding screen and paper wall paintings, all dedicated Important Cultural Properties, done by artists of the Kano school adorn the rooms of the Ohojo which includes the willow room, musk room, lunch room, flower and bird room (west room), crane room and Narutaki room.

A total of 120 sliding screen and paper wall paintings, all dedicated Important Cultural Properties, done by artists of the Kano school adorn the rooms of the Ohojo which includes the willow room, musk room, lunch room, flower and bird room (west room), crane room and Narutaki room.

sen.j: これらは旧御所の障壁画を引き継いだものであるが、建物の移築に際して襖の配置構成が大幅に変更されており、本来ひと続きの画面であった襖が別々の部屋に配置されているものも多い。
sen.e: These were inherited from the old imperial palace but when the building was moved, the configuration of the sliding screens was drastically changed and many that were once part of a continuous series became placed in different rooms.

These were inherited from the old imperial palace but when the building was moved, the configuration of the sliding screens was drastically changed and many that were once part of a continuous series became placed in different rooms.

These were inherited from the old imperial palace but when the building was moved, the configuration of the sliding screens was drastically changed and many that were once part of a continuous series became placed in different rooms.

sen.j: 小方丈の障壁画は狩野探幽の作と伝えられるが、作風上からは数名の絵師による作と推測されている。
sen.e: It is said that the partition paintings in the Kohojo are the work of Tanshin KANO, but the style has led to speculation that they are in fact the work of numerous artists.
It is said that the partition paintings in the Kohojo are the work of Tanyu KANO, but the style has led to speculation that they are in fact the work of numerous artists.
It is said that the partition paintings in the Kohojo are the work of Tanyu KANO, but the style has led to speculation that they are in fact the work of numerous artists.

sen.j: 名勝に指定されている方丈前の枯山水庭園は小堀遠州作といわれ、「虎の子渡しの庭」の通称がある。
sen.e: The dry landscape garden, commonly known as 'Tora-no-Ko Watashi-no-Niwa', at the front of the hojo is said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI and has been designated a place of scenic beauty.
The dry landscape garden, commonly known as 'Tora-no-Ko Watashi-no-Niwa', at the front of the hojo is said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI and has been designated a place of scenic beauty.

The dry landscape garden, commonly known as 'Tora-no-Ko Watashi-no-Niwa (The crossing of tigercubs),' at the front of the hojo is said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI and has been designated a place of scenic beauty.

sen.j: 南禅寺の塔頭のひとつで、勅使門の手前右側に位置する。
sen.e: This sub-temple is situated to the front right of the Chokushimon Gate.
This is one of the sub-temples of Nanzen-ji Temple is situated to the front right of the Chokushi-mon Gate.
sen.cmt: This is one of the sub-temples of Nanzen-ji Templeに訂正。Chokushi-monに訂正。
sen.e: This is one of the sub-temples of Nanzen-ji Temple which is situated to the front right of the Chokushi-mon Gate.

sen.j: 応永、洛北鷹ヶ峰（北区 (京都市)に大業和尚が創建し、慶長10年（1605年）頃以心崇伝によって現在地に移築された。
sen.e: Established during the Oei era (1394-1428) by Daigo Osho in the Takagamine area of the Rakuhoku distrct (Kita Ward, Kyoto City) and relocated to its current location by Ishin Suden in around 1605.
Established during the Oei era (1394-1428) by Daigo Osho in the Takagamine area of the Rakuhoku district (Kita Ward, Kyoto City) and relocated to its current location by Ishin Suden in around 1605.

sen.j: 方丈は桃山城の遺構を慶長16年（1611年）に移築したものという。
sen.e: The Hojo was relocated from Momoyama Castle in 1611.
The Hojo was relocated from the remains of Momoyama Castle in 1611.
The Hojo was relocated from the remains of Momoyama Castle in 1611.

sen.j: 特別名勝に指定されている庭園は「鶴亀の庭」と言われ、小堀遠州の作という。
sen.e: The garden named 'Tsurukame-no-Niwa' (Garden of Cranes and Turtles) is a designated place of scenic beauty and said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI.
The garden named 'Tsurukame-no-Niwa' (Garden of Cranes and Turtles) is a designated place of scenic beauty and said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI.

sen.j: 亀山上皇の離宮時代の「上の宮」跡に造られた南禅寺の塔頭で、南禅寺発祥の地といわれる。
sen.e: This sub-temple was constructed on the site of the upper palace of ex-emperor Kameyama's detached palace and is considered to be the origin of Nanzen-ji Temple.
This sub-temple was constructed on the site of the upper palace of ex-emperor Kameyama's detached palace and is considered to be the origin of Nanzen-ji Temple.
This sub-temple was constructed on the site of the upper palace of retired Emperor Kameyama's detached palace and is considered to be the origin of Nanzen-ji Temple.

tit.cmt: ・Boiled Tofu: 英辞郎 on the WEB

sen.j: 湯豆腐は南禅寺周辺参道の勧進料理が起源とされている。
sen.e: It is believed that boiled tofu originated as a way for the temple to raise money.
It is believed that boiled tofu originated from 'Kanjin dish (dish for donation)' on the approach to Nanzenji Temple.
sen.cmt: 勧進料理→Kanjin dish (dish for donation)
sen.e: It is believed that boiled tofu originated from Kanjin dish (dish for donation) on the approach to Nanzen-ji Temple.

sen.j: 山形県鶴岡市では「南禅寺豆腐」というほぼ半球の形をした豆腐が名産。
sen.e: The almost hemispherical 'Nanzan-ji Tofu' is a specialty of Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture.
The almost hemispherical 'Nanzan-ji Tofu' is a specialty of Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture.
The almost hemispherical 'Nanzan-ji Tofu' is a specialty of Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture.

sen.j: 江戸時代に北前船に乗って京都から西廻り航路で伝わったといわれている。
sen.e: It is said to have made its way from Kyoto on the cargo ships that sailed the Sea of Japan during the Edo period.
It is said to have made its way from Kyoto on the cargo ships that sailed the Sea of Japan during the Edo period.
It is said to have made its way from Kyoto on the cargo ships that sailed the Sea of Japan during the Edo period.

sen.j: 5月から8月中旬までの間の期間限定販売。
sen.e: Only sold from May to mid-August.
Only sold from May to mid-August.
Only sold from May to mid-August.
